channel.title: Rick Perry's call to prayer draws crowd of 30,000
channel.description:
http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/aug/07/rick-perrys-call-to-prayer
Is it appropriate for someone who is the governor of a US state and also plans (or seems to be planning) to run for President of the USA to organise such a thing?

item.title: Rick Perry's call to prayer draws crowd of 30,000
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

didn’t rick perry also want texas to secede from the us?

Read full topic

item.title: Rick Perry's call to prayer draws crowd of 30,000
item.dc:creator: @Echo3 Echo_
item.description:
@Echo3 wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:10, topic:408933”][quote author=Echo_ link=topic=510215.msg3702267#msg3702267 date=1312821879]
All he has to do is say he’s Christian and they are on his side.
[/quote]Are you serious? Every president known to date has said they are Christian or Catholic, people still need to make choices :P[/quote]

True, most presidents have included that as a sidenote. But this guy is going overboard with it, it’s almost like it’s his main argument of why you should vote for him.

Read full topic

item.title: Rick Perry's call to prayer draws crowd of 30,000
item.dc:creator: @Echo3 Echo_
item.description:
@Echo3 wrote:

"The Christian voting bloc is a force to contend with."

He’s just trying to get the votes from the people that don’t take much convincing. All he has to do is say he’s Christian and they are on his side.

As for the original question, I don’t believe it’s appropriate to do this considering the fact that there are many different religions (if not all) practiced in the USA. This is no theocracy, so it should not be run like one.

Read full topic
item.source: Rick Perry's call to prayer draws crowd of 30,000

item.source: Rick Perry's call to prayer draws crowd of 30,000

item.title: Rick Perry's call to prayer draws crowd of 30,000
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

Davidi2:

In other words, is someone in political office not allowed to profess their faith anymore?

Of course they are. I’m just a little unsure if, given the country’s brilliant secular foundations, is it appropriate to be the one organising such things?

I’m not sure myself. Sure, he is perfectly within his right to practice his religion, but doing so in such a way that represents his political position like this:

http://texasndp.org/documents/2011aug6.pdf
http://texasndp.org/documents/2011prayfast.pdf

Is going a little too far, isn’t it?

Read full topic
item.source: Rick Perry's call to prayer draws crowd of 30,000

item.title: Rick Perry's call to prayer draws crowd of 30,000
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Budda, post:3, topic:408933”]Its more the fact that religion should be completely separate from matters of state.[/quote][quote=“Davidi2, post:2, topic:408933”]In other words, is someone in political office not allowed to profess their faith anymore?[/quote]Because you see, someone in political office is state, whereas their faith is religion.

I don’t see the problem, unless he was making it some official governmental meeting.

Read full topic
